title: Pharmacokinetic considerations for certain groups
detail:
• Ability to biotransform or eliminate drugs may be compromised in geriatric and younger patients, therefore drug doses are decreased or dose interval is increased
• A neonate's liver may not be completely functional until several weeks of age, which decreases biotransformation and makes neonate less tolerant

title: Pharmacodynamics
detail:
• Effects of drugs and their mechanisms of action on the body
• Biochemical and physiologic effects of drugs
• Mechanism of action (MOA): Drugs often “act” by interacting with a target protein like a receptor in a specific cell; agonists activate and antagonists block (exception are drugs that produce effects on the basis of their physical characteristics)
• Side effects (adverse reactions): Commonly linked to MOA and result from the interaction of the drug with other cells than the target cell/tissue, alteration of patient’s physiology, or pharmacokinetics
• Dose dependent reactions: Predictable, affects all, increase w dose

title: Pharmacognosy
detail: • Study of crude drugs obtained from medicinal plants, animals, fungi, and other natural sources

title: Pharmacogenetics
detail: • Genetic variations that cause different responses to drugs in different individuals

title: Therapeutic index (therapeutic ratio)
detail:
• Relative safety of a drug
• Expressed as
TI = LD50 / EC50
LD50 is the lethal dosage for 50% of a population
EC50 is the minimum effective concentration for 50% of the same population
• Higher the TI, safer the drug
• Low TI means the dosage range bw safe and toxic results is very small (few dosage options before adverse effects)

title: Therapeutic drug monitoring
detail:
• Periodic measurement of the amount of a drug in the blood
• Used most often w NSAIDs, cardiac drugs, anticonvulsants, and thyroid drugs
• Used when a drug is used long-term (e.g. phenobarbital)

title: Therapeutic range
detail: • Plasma concentration at which therapeutic benefits should be observed

title: Loading dose
detail:
• Initial administration of a large dose followed by smaller doses
• Brings serum concentration to a therapeutic level quickly
• Common w phenobarbital (anticonvulsant)

title: Half-life (t1/2)
detail:
• Time required for the amount of a drug in the body to decrease by 50%
• Each half-life gets you half of the remaining distance toward steady state (not half of the original dose)
• Each half-life lowers drug concentration by half of the level it was at the beginning of that half-life
• Estimates the duration of a drug’s effect, so used to estimate dosing interval
• Also used to establish withdrawal time in food-producing animals (i.e., period when food products contain unacceptable amounts of the drug—may cause allergies, antibiotic resistance)
• Time needed to reach steady state, or time required for 97% of the drug to be removed, is approximately 5x the half-life

title: Steady state
detail:
• Aka distribution equilibrium
• Point at which drug accumulation equals drug elimination
• Amount of drug leaving the plasma for tissue equals amount of drug leaving the tissue for the plasma, meaning that the plasma concentration of a drug is consistent at its highest concentration (peak) and lowest concentration (trough)

title: Steady state vs. half-life
detail: • A drug reaches steady state after approximately five half-lives, when the rate of administration equals the rate of elimination and plasma concentrations plateau

title: Drug accumulation (organs)
detail:
• Some drugs will stay in the tissue until blood concentration drops to create a concentration gradient, moving into blood after gradient occurs
• Organs in which drugs accumulate include liver, kidney, bone, and fat

title: Parenteral
detail: • Drugs given by injection

title: Anaphylactic shock
detail:
• An allergic reaction severe enough to cause death
• Low BP, itching, swelling, extreme respiratory problems
• Treated w IV diphenhydramine (Benadryl)

title: Antihistamines
detail:
• Drugs that block histamine release or reuptake
• Can prevent or reduce allergic reactions
• Multimodal therapy is common since allergy response involves multiple factors in the body
• Usually produce drowsiness, dry mouth, thirst

title: Mechanism of action for antihistamines
detail:
• Work by blocking H1 or H2 receptors
• H1 receptors are responsible for pruritus and movement of inflammatory cells to a site
• H2 receptors stimulate gastric acid secretion and regulate immune responses
• H1 blockers antagonize histamine at receptor sites (don’t block its release) (Benadryl, Claritin)
• Effective for anaphylaxis bc they stop bronchoconstriction and vasodilation
• Less effective as anti-inflammatory response or allergy treatment since histamines aren’t the only cause of inflammation
• H2 antagonists suppress gastric secretory effects and have mild anti-inflammatory effects (famotidine)

title: Antihistamine drugs
detail:
• Chlorpheniramine
• Cyproheptadine (used to enhance appetite in cats as well)
• Diphenhydramine (Benadryl)
• Hydroxyzine
• Clemastine

title: Diphenhydramine
detail:
• Histamine (H1) blocker
• Used as an antiemetic (for motion sickness), for pruritus, and allergic reactions
• Can be used in mast cell tumor removal surgery to prevent the effects of massive histamine release when tumor is manipulated and before it is aspirated

title: Antimicrobial drugs
detail:
• Antibacterial drugs (antibiotics)
	• Vomiting and diarrhea most common side effect due to effects on GI flora and irritation of stomach
• Antifungal drugs
• Systemic (ketoconazole) or topical antifungals

title: Antibiotics
detail:
• Used to stop bacterial infections; bacteriostatic or bactericidal
• Broad spectrum antibiotics are effective against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but its overprescription is the reason for antibiotic resistance
• Only way to know the correct antibiotic to be used is to run a culture and sensitivity test of the infected area

title: Classes of antibiotic drugs (book 1)
detail:
• Beta-lactams
• Penicillins (end in -in)
• Cephalosporins (start w cef- or ceph-)
• Carbapenems
• Monobactams
• Chloramphenicol
• Lincosamides (e.g. clindamycin)
• Fluoroquinolones (end in -floxacin or -oxacin)
• Aminoglycosides (e.g. gentamicin, neomycin)
• Macrolides (e.g. erythromycin)
• Tetracyclines (end in -cycline or -tetracycline)

title: Classes of antibiotic drugs (book 2)
detail:
• Penicillins (G, V, Amoxicillin)
• Cephalosporins (Cefazolin, Cephalexin)
• Aminoglycosides (Gentamicin, Neomycin)
• Sulfonamides (Sulfadiazine)
• Fluoroquinolones (Enrofloxacin, Cipro)
• Macrolides (Erythromycin)
• Linosamides (Clindamycin)
• Tetracyclines (Doxycycline)
• Carbapenems (Meropenem)
• Chloramphenicol

title: Beta-lactams
detail:
• Used in dogs, cats, poultry, and large animals to treat streptococcal and clostridial infections
• Bactericidal
• Inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis by targeting penicillin-binding proteins
• Penicillins and monobactams are narrow spectrum
• Carbapenems are broad spectrum
• Cephalosporins depend on generation—1st gen are narrow, 2nd to 4th are broad
• 1st gen include cefazolin, cephalexin; should not be used in animals allergic to penicillin

title: Cephalosporins
detail:
• Each generation is more resistant to beta-lactamase than the previous
• First generation (e.g., cefazolin, cephalexin) has good gram-positive and poor gram-negative coverage
• Gram-negative coverage gets better w each following generation

title: Lincosamides
detail:
• Bactericidal or bacteriostatic depending on species and severity of infection
• Moderate spectrum
• Inhibit protein synthesis
• Effective against most anaerobes
• Include clindamycin, lincomycin
• Not used on horses

title: Fluoroquinolones
detail:
• Used in cats, dogs, ruminants, pigs, horses
• Can be used to treat infections of the skin, bladder, ears, kidneys, lungs (pneumonia), and prostate
• Gram-positive, gram-negative, pseudomonas (no effect against anaerobes)
• Bactericidal
• Inhibit nucleic acid synthesis (inhibit DNA)
• Mostly narrow spectrum, except 3rd gen broad spectrum
• Include ciprofloxacin, enrofloxacin (Baytril), etc.
• Doesn’t disrupt GI flora, so safe for use in rabbits
• Can cause lesions in the joint cartilage of rapidly growing animals and impair cartilage development
• FDA bans use in food animals
• Retinal degeneration and blindness may occur in cats, so dosed at lower end (esp. Baytril)

title: Aminoglycosides
detail:
• Used to treat severe infection only bc they are nephrotoxic and ototoxic
• Used to treat Enterobacteriaceae (e.g. E. coli)
• Bactericidal
• Inhibit protein synthesis
• Broad spectrum, but not effective against anaerobic bacteria—they require an environment w high oxygen tension to be transported into the bacteria
• Include gentamicin, amikacin, neomycin
• Severely nephrotoxic when administered by injection, but not absorbed systemically when given PO and poorly absorbed when applied topically, so these routes used often
• Pus-filled wounds or ear canals with purulent debris must be thoroughly cleaned before applying a topical aminoglycosides bc necrotic debris will bind (attach to the nucleic acids of dead WBCs) and cause them to be ineffective

title: Aminoglycoside drugs
detail:
• Amikacin is used for serious gram-neg infections; oto- and nephrotoxic; can become pale yellow w/out effect to its efficacy
• Neomycin is more nephrotoxic than other aminoglycosides; used topically for skin, eyes, ears, and PO for enteric infections
• Gentamicin (Otomax) is used w caution in patients w chronic kidney failure; can be ototoxic

title: Macrolides
detail:
• Used to treat respiratory issues, skin/soft tissue infections (staph/strep), GI infections (swine dysentery), and specific conditions like eye infections in cats
• Bacteriostatic (unless at high concentrations)
• Narrow spectrum (gram-positive)
• Inhibit protein synthesis
• Bind to subunit 50s, impairing a translocation step of protein synthesis
• Include erythromycin, which is used in case of penicillin allergy

title: Chloramphenicol
detail:
• Used in pets to treat anaerobic infections including middle and inner ear and eye infections, and salmonellosis
• Bacteriostatic
• Broad spectrum
• Inhibits protein synthesis
• Illegal to use on food animals bc it’s known to cause aplastic anemia in humans (should be applied w gloves)
• Side effects include V/D, anaphylaxis
• Inhibit drug-metabolizing enzymes and hepatic metabolism of other drugs, so should be used w caution when used w medications metabolized by the liver (e.g. phenobarbital)
• Cats and neonates can’t conjugate or excrete it, which can lead to toxicity and circulatory collapse
• Cats are also more susceptible to chloramphenicol-induced bone marrow suppression (reversible)
• Crosses blood–brain and corneal barrier

title: Tetracyclines
detail:
• Used to treat local and systemic infections, but resistance increased a lot
• Bacteriostatic
• Inhibit protein synthesis
• Broad spectrum
• Effective against mycoplasma, spirochetes, chlamydia, and rickettsial diseases like Rocky Mountain spotted fever
• Chelate w calcium, leading to yellow, mottled teeth and slow bone development in young animals
• Should not be given with food since chelating w calcium will cause a decrease in absorption; iron, aluminum, magnesium should also be avoided
• Include doxycycline, oxytetracycline, chlortetracycline

title: Mechanism of action of antibiotics
detail:
• Beta-lactams interfere w cell wall synthesis
• Lincosemides interfere w protein synthesis
• Tetracyclines interfere w protein synthesis
• Aminoglycosides interfere w protein synthesis
• Macrolides interfere w protein synthesis
• Fluoroquinolones interfere w nucleic acid (DNA) synthesis

title: Efficacy of antibiotics in different cases (inflammation, shock, necrosis in case of bite wound on leg)
detail:
• Chronic inflammation causes purulent discharge and an acidic/hypoxic environment, which can inhibit efficacy of antibiotics
• Acute inflammation increases delivery to the area because of vasodilation and increase in blood flow to the area
• Shock causes body to shunt blood to the vital organs thereby decreasing blood flow to the extremities, which will decrease delivery of the drug but not necessarily efficacy
• Necrosis will result in no delivery of drug to the area because of a complete lack of blood flow

title: Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC)
detail:
• Lowest concentration of an antimicrobial drug that inhibits the grown of an organism
• Represents the degree of susceptibility of an organism to a specific concentration of a particular antibiotic at its lowest effective dose

title: Antifungals
detail:
• Work by distinguishing mammalian cells from fungi cells (mammalian cell walls contain cholesterol, fungi cell walls contain ergosterol)
• Some work by causing DNA mutations, but may also mutate mammalian DNA, leading to birth defects

title: Classes of antifungal drugs
detail:
• Polyenes (make fungi cell wall permeable, causing contents to spill out resulting in cell death)
• Azoles (block essential enzyme for cell wall synthesis, resulting in loss of cell wall integrity)
• Triazoles (flucanozole, itraconazole)— preferred due to less effects and better results
• Imidazoles (miconazole, ketoconazole)
• Allylamines (terbinafine) (used to treat dermatophytosis (ringworm))

title: Administration of antifungals
detail:
• Fluconazole, itraconazole and ketoconazole are administered orally for systemic and dermatologic infections
• Miconazole is administered topically for skin and ears in cats and dogs

title: Itraconazole
detail:
• Used to treat systemic mycoses like dermatophytes (ringworm)
• More effective and expensive than ketoconazole
• Can cause anorexia and hepatic toxicity in dogs

title: Antiparasitics
detail:
• Bemzimidazoles (Fenbendazole) – nematodes, lungworms, cestodes, giardia
• Tetrahydropyrimidines (Pyrantel) – lungworms/nematodes
• Prazinquantel – tapeworms/cestodes, flukes/trematodes
• Avermectins (Ivermectin, Sekamection) and Milbemycins (moxidectin) – nematodes, arthropods
• Metronidazole (Flagyl) – giardia, balantidium coli

title: Types of helminths
detail:
• Helminths are parasitic worms
• Trematodes are flukes (flat, leaf-shaped worms)
• Cestodes are tapeworms (flat, segmented worms)
• Flea tapeworm – Dipylidium caninum
• Taenia species
• Echinococcus species
• Nematodes are roundworms (round, segmented)
• Ascarids – Toxocara, Toxascaris
• Hookworms – Ancylostoma, Uncinaria
• Whipworms – Trichuris
• Heartworms – Dirofilaria immitis
• Lungworms

title: Moxidectin
detail:
• Antiparasitic in the class milbemycin
• Preventive for D. immitis in dogs; eliminates tissue stage of heartworm larvae; microfilaricide
• Closely related to avermectins

title: Ivermectin
detail:
• Monthly preventive for dogs and cats
• Plus formula (Heartgard Plus) in dogs is effective against hookworms and roundworms
• In cats, preventive for D. immitis and removal of hookworms
• Given PO, SC, IM
• Can cross the blood-brain barrier in collies, some types of shepherds, whippets, and sheepdogs because of an MDR1 (multidrug resistance protein 1) mutation—MDR1 prevents entry into cells and is found in intestines, liver, kidney, and blood–brain barrier; mutation causes these dogs to be more susceptible to adverse drug reactions

title: Pyrantel
detail:
• Used in dogs to remove tapeworms, hookworms, roundworms, whipworms
• Drug class tetrahydropyrimidines

title: Microfilariae
detail: • Immature heartworms

title: Macrocyclic lactones
detail:
• Avermectins and milbemycins
• Broad spectrum; various nematodes and arthropods, also as heartworm preventive in dogs
• Some species are sensitive (Collies) so used with caution in dogs

title: Ectoparasiticides
detail:
• Contact insecticides (pyrethrins, indoxacarb, lime sulfur)
• Drugs that target parasite’s nervous system (amitraz, avermectins)
• Insect growth regulators (lufeneron, pyripoxifen)

title: Heartworm treatment
detail:
• Multimodal treatment—an adulticide to kill off the adult HWs, ivermectin to eliminate larvae, an anti-inflammatory to minimize inflammation associated w HW presence, and a doxycycline to reduce numbers of Wolbachia
Case: Ivermectin + Melarsomine + Glucocorticoid + Prednisone + Doxycycline
• Exercise restriction is essential since pulmonary embolism from dead worms is a risk

title: Heartworm drugs
detail:
• Adulticide: Melarsomine (Immiticide)
• Only approved adulticide
• Arsenic compound; administered deep IM in lumbar region
• Contraindicated in dogs w severe HW disease
• Microfilaricides: Ivermectin, milbemycin, and moxidectin
• Given 4 weeks after last adulticide

title: Pyrethrins
detail:
• Family of contact insecticides
• Target fleas, ticks, mites, and mosquitoes
• Quick-kill effect w low residual activity
• Include permethrin, phenothrin, etofenprox
• Dips, sprays, shampoos, foggers,
• Always used w a synergist to maximize effect
• Not safe for cats

title: Types of vaccines
detail:
• Live vaccines (aka modified or attuned vaccines): Strong immune response, most protection; strict storage and handling requirements
• Killed (inactivated) vaccines: Lesser immune response due to killed pathogen; usually requires 2 doses initially, followed by annual vaccination; more stable and easier to store
• Recombinant (DNA) vaccines: Non-disease-causing components produced by the pathogen are transmitted to a different organism that is introduced to the animal (immune system recognizes the same component in the pathogen and starts a response)
• Toxoid vaccines: Short-lived humoral immune response resulting from attenuated toxins

title: Antigens
detail:
• Protein molecules found on the outer surface of disease-causing pathogens
• Cause the body to create antibodies to fight disease

title: Anaphylactic reaction to vaccines
detail:
• Normally happen w/in 24 hours
• Can happen on the 1st vaccine or later
• Causes itching, weakness, apnea, sudden V/D, facial swelling, pale gums, seizures
• If untreated, can lead to respiratory and heart failure, shock
• Tx w epinephrine, antihistamines, oxygen therapy, IV fluids if needed

title: Antiarrhythmic drugs
detail:
• Used to restore normal electrical activity in the heart
• Class I (A/B) Sodium channel blockers (lidocaine and procainamide) limit the flow of sodium, slowing down conduction; used mainly for ventricular arrhythmias
• Class II Beta-adrenergic blockers (propranolol) obstruct beta-adrenergic receptors which reduces sympathetic stimulation of the heart, decreasing HR and AV conduction
• Also negative inotropes (decrease contractility)
• Class IV Calcium channel blockers (verapamil and diltiazem) slow down conduction and prolong refractory periods; used mainly for supraventricular arrhythmias
• Also negative inotropes (decrease contractility)
• Positive inotropes (digoxin and catecholamines) make heart contractions stronger, improving cardiac output

title: Lidocaine
detail:
• Local anesthetic and antiarrhythmic
• Sodium channel blocker—limits the flow of sodium, slowing down conduction
• Used mainly for ventricular arrhythmias
• Myocardium's response to lidocaine and other class I antiarrhythmic drugs depends on the presence of potassium; hypokalemia will decrease efficacy
• Can be diluted w sodium bicarbonate to change the acidity of lidocaine and decrease burning during injection (9 parts lidocaine to 1 part sodium bicarbonate [1:0.9])
• Lidocaine toxicity causes central nervous signs (due to inhibition of excitatory neurons) including drowsiness, ataxia, and muscle tremors; seizures possible at higher doses
• Causes sinus arrest as a result of cardiac suppression if administered too quickly
• Should not exceed 6 to 8 mg/kg

title: Bupivacaine
detail:
• Local anesthetic
• Blocks sodium channels needed for nerve signal transmission

title: Reperfusion injury
detail:
• Occurs when oxygen delivery is restored to tissue after a period of ischemia (lack of oxygen)—ischemia causes damage, which is made worse when blood flow returns and brings inflammatory factors and free radicals
• Lidocaine acts as a free radical scavenger and prevents or decreases damage

title: Inotropic vs. chronotropic drugs
detail:
• Inotropic drugs affect the force of cardiac muscle contractions
• A positive inotrope will increase cardiac contractility whereas a negative inotrope will decrease contractility
• Chronotropic drugs affect HR
• A chronotropic agent will increase (positive) or decrease (negative) HR

title: Digoxin
detail:
• Positive inotrope and negative chronotrope
• Makes heart contractions stronger, improving cardiac output
• Decreases HR
• A cardiac glycoside (digitalis compound)
• Used to treat CHF, atrial fibrillation, and supraventricular tachycardia
• Side effects include GI signs (vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia) and cardiac arrhythmias
• Hypokalemia increases risk of digoxin toxicity—digoxin prefers to bind to the Sodium-Potassium Pump at the same place that potassium binds, so in its absence more of it can bind

title: Catecholamines
detail:
• Adrenergic agents are classified as catecholamines and noncatecholamines
• Increase the force and rate of heart contractions (increase cardiac output), constrict peripheral vessels (increase BP), and elevate blood glucose levels
• Increase in cardiac contractility is mainly due to stimulation of beta1 receptors
• Used for short-term management of severe heart failure due to short half-life
• Include epinephrine, isoproterenol, dopamine, dobutamine
• Can predispose heart to arrhythmias

title: Thrombolytics (fibrinolytics)
detail:
• Thrombolytics break up and dissolve blood clots by activating plasmin, the enzyme that separates and disintegrates fibrin strands
• v.s. anticoagulants, which prevent clotting from happening in the first place (but cannot break up clots that have already formed)
• Include t-PA (alteplase Activase), streptokinase, and urokinase

title: Anticoagulants
detail:
• Stop formation of blood clots
• Blood clots are formed during coagulation by the protein thrombin, which is an enzyme that increases conversion rate of fibrinogen to fibrin (which induces the blood to clot)
• More effective in treating thromboembolism in animals

title: Anticoagulant drugs and their uses
detail:
• Heparin: Often added to sterile saline to produce heparinized saline, which can be used to flush intravenous catheters
• EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid): Used in blood tubes; also added to calcium disodium to chelate zinc or lead in zinc/lead toxicity cases
• Acid citrate dextrose: Used in blood collection bags for transfusions

title: Heparin
detail:
• Anticoagulant
• Found in tissues; obtained from pig intestinal mucosa
• Prevents conversion of prothrombin (factor II) to thrombin, w/out which fibrinogen won’t be converted to fibrin so clot won’t be formed
• Unfractionated heparin blocks the activity of thrombin, low molecular weight heparin doesn’t

title: Hemoglobin
detail:
• Iron-containing protein in RBCs
• Crucial for transporting oxygen and carbon dioxide

title: Hematinics
detail:
• Blood-building products
• Used to treat anemia (low hemoglobin), to increase the level of hemoglobin in the blood
• Three types include erythropoietin (aka hematopoietin or hemopoietin), androgens, and blood substitutes (oxyglobin)
• Androgens stimulate kidney’s production of erythropoietin but have secondary effects so use is limited
• Oxyglobin is bovine hemoglobin; provides oxygen-carrying capacity for up to 40 hours

title: Erythropoietin
detail:
• Hormone secreted by the kidneys
• Causes release of RBCs from the bone marrow
• In renal failure, kidneys are often damaged so they don’t produce enough (or at all), leading to nonregenerative anemia
• Parenteral androgens like nandrolone and testosterone enanthate, as well as human recombinant erythropoietin injections can be given to treat anemia (latter is expensive and antibody formation possible, so last choice)

title: Hemostatic drugs
detail: • Used to induce clotting and to stop hemorrhage

title: Erythropoietin
detail:
• Hormone produced by the kidney, and to a lesser extent the liver if levels go down
• Regulates production of RBCs; stimulates bone marrow to produce RBCs
• Insufficient production will lead to anemia
• Renal diseases causes a decrease in its production so supplementation may be beneficial

title: Oxyglobin
detail:
• A blood substitute that can be given to anemic animals
• Derived from chemically stabilized bovine hemoglobin
• Short-term increase and maintenance of oxygen levels

title: Use of crystalloid and colloid solutions
detail:
• Isotonic solutions are used to support perfusion and volume replacement
• Hypertonic solutions are used to draw fluid from intracellular space to intravascular space; useful when large amounts of fluids are needed quickly
• Hypotonic solutions are used to move fluid from intravascular space to intracellular space; mostly used to correct electrolyte imbalances
• Colloids are used to restore organ perfusion; used in pulmonary contusions and head trauma; resuscitation is achieved w a lower rate since colloids stay in the vascular space longer than crystalloids

title: Blood products
detail:
• Fresh whole blood: Used in hemorrhagic shock, anemia, excessive surgical hemorrhage, clotting disorders, non-IMHA, sometimes IMHA
• Crystalloids combined w packed RBCs: Used when fluid balance and osmotic pressure need to be maintained (crystalloids used to expand blood volume)

title: Analgesics
detail:
• NSAIDs (phenylbutazone, aspirin, ibuprofen, etodolac, carprofen, flunixin)
• Opioids (morphine, meperidine, butorphanol, codeine)
• Corticosteroids (prednisone, dexamethasone)

title: Opioids
detail:
• Pure mu agonists: More effective analgesia, but side effects like vomiting, respiratory depression, sedation; include morphine, hydromorphone, fentanyl, meperidine
• Simbadol is a high-concentration buprenorphine w 24-hour action if given sc (6 hrs if IM); used in cats but metabolized in the liver so not for liver disease
• Partial mu agonists: Bind w the less effective analgesic receptor (k receptor); include buprenorphine
• Mu antagonist: Reverses the effects of pure mu agonists, weakening analgesic effects; include butorphanol

title: Common side effects of opioids
detail:
• Bradycardia
• Respiratory depression
• Hypotension
• Excitement
• Vomiting
• Ileus
• Large animals tend to experience anxiety w opioid agonists due to mu-receptor activity
• Hyperthermia and mydriasis possible in large animals and cats

title: NSAIDs
detail:
• Block production of prostaglandins that promote pain and inflammation
• Reduction of pain is thru reduction of inflammation that triggers the pain sensation
• Also have antipyretic effects
• Baseline and annual blood work to check kidney and liver function is necessary for long-term use
• Side effects include kidney and liver toxicity, GI ulcers, stomach bleeding, V/D, loss of appetite, lethargy
• Because some NSAIDs inhibit COX-1 (involved w renal perfusion and gastric mucosa maintenance) side effects can include renal failure and gastric ulceration
• Cats have the longest half-life

title: Tranquilizers
detail:
• Decrease anxiety w/out causing excessive sedation or drowsiness
• Usually aware of surroundings but don’t care
• vs. sedatives—suppress brain activity and awareness, have some analgesia
• No analgesia
• Include phenothiazines and benzodiazepines

title: Phenothiazines
detail:
• Tranquilizers—sedation and antianxiety
• Block dopamine and alpha-adrenergic receptors
• Antiemetic effects due to depression of chemoreceptor trigger zone
• Mild antipruritic effect
• No analgesic effects
• Reduce tendency of epinephrine to induce cardiac arrhythmias
• Include acepromazine, chlorpromazine
• Main side effects is hypotension due to vasodilation (alpha blockade); also include hypothermia, HR changes, aggression, excitement, sweating, lowered seizure threshold
• Should not be used w/in 1 month of deworming w organophosphates

title: Benzodiazepines
detail:
• Tranquilizers—sedatives w muscle relaxation
• Provide sedation by depressing the limbic system, thalamus, and hypothalamus
• Muscle-relaxing effects due to inhibition of neurons on the spinal cord
• Some like diazepam are anticonvulsants too
• Metabolized thru the liver and excreted thru urine, so caution in liver and kidney disease
• Side effects include CNS depression, ataxia, weakness, disorientation, nausea, vomiting
• Excitation right before depression possible

title: Alpha 2 agonists
detail:
• Sedatives that provide analgesia and muscle relaxation
• Cardiovascular effects like bradycardia, hypertension, and reduced cardiac output possible
• Not to be used in cardiovascular, liver, and kidney disease
• Include medetomidine (Domitor), dexmedetomidine, xylazine

title: Medetomidine
detail:
• Domitor
• Alpha 2 agonist
• Potent anxiolytic, hypnotic, anticonvulsant, muscle relaxant, sedative, analgesic
• Side effects include bradycardia, hypothermia, decreased respiration, urination, AV blocks, vomiting
• Caution especially in very young/old animals
• Reversed w atipamezole (Antisedan)

title: Dexmedetomidine
detail:
• Dexdomitor
• Alpha 2 agonist
• Used as a sedative; premed for general anesthesia
• When combined w morphine as an epidural, increases length of analgesia
• Side effects include bradycardia and hypertension—the hypertension results in a reflex bradycardia, which is why patients can have low HR coupled w normal BP
• Reversed w atipamezole (Antisedan)

title: Atipamezole (Antisedan)
detail:
• Effective in 5-10 min
• Preferred over yohimbine due to less side effects
• Can cause transient behavioral problems like extreme nervousness
• Can cause hypotension so BP should be monitored
• HR and RR may increase
• Nausea and vomiting possible
• Diarrhea, hypersalivation, shivering, overstimulation possible
• Not for pregnant and nursing animals

title: Yohimbine
detail:
• Reverses xylazine, medetomidine, and dexmedetomidine
• Atipamezole can be used instead in small mammals

title: Xylazine
detail:
• Rompun, Anased
• Alpha 2 agonist
• Sedative, analgesic, muscle relaxant
• Effective analgesic in horses (used for colic); used w ketamine for short-term field procedures
• Ruminants are very sensitive (causes decreased rumen motility); 1/10 of horse dose used
• Causes vomiting in many cats and some dogs
• Other side effects include bradycardia, hypotension, respiratory depression, increased sensitivity to epinephrine leading to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac conduction disturbances, myocardial depression
• Reversed w yohimbine

title: Neuroleptanalgesics
detail:
• Opioid + Sedative/Tranquilizer
• Opioid + Phenothiazine (Acepromazine)
• Opioid + Benzodiazepine (Diazepam)
• Opioid + Alpha-2 Agonist (Dexmedetomidine)

title: Anticonvulsants
detail:
• Phenobarbital for long-term seizure control (oral)
• Potassium bromide and sodium bromide can be used in addition in dogs if phenobarbital alone isn’t enough or can’t be used
• Common side effect of phenobarbital is hepatotoxicity, so can’t be used in pre-existing liver disease

title: Antidepressants
detail:
• Clomipramine (Clomicalm) used for separation anxiety
• Selegeline (Anipryl) used for canine cognitive dysfunction

title: Cholinergic vs. adrenergic
detail:
• Adrenergic agents stimulate sympathetic processes, principally by releasing epinephrine and norepinephrine
• Cholinergic agents engage the parasympathetic processes, principally by producing, altering, mimicking, or releasing acetylcholine
• Adrenergic blockers and anticholinergics can be used to circumvent the agents

title: Anticholinergics
detail:
• Used to decrease effects of parasympathetic nervous system stimulation such as bradycardia and excessive salivation
• Block acetylcholine at cholinergic sites, causing a decrease in salivation, tear production, and GI motility, and inhibiting bradycardia caused by vagal stimulation (block nerve impulses from reaching the vagus nerve)
• Aminopentamide slows down GI motility
• Atropine and glycopyrrolate increase HR, dilate pupils, dry up secretions
• Glycopyrrolate is more predictable in rabbits
• Can be used alongside opioids
• Not in case of high risk for tachycardia (often geriatric patients), history of CHF, or patients w constipation or ileus

title: Emetics
detail:
• Work by irritating the gastric mucosa, which stimulates the CNS and causes vomiting
• Include apomorphine, hydrogen peroxide, xylazine, syrup of ipecac
• Apomorphine is used in case of ingestion of toxic substance; pills can be crushed and put in the conjunctival sac, but must be washed out to prevent prolonged vomiting
• Activated charcoal should not be administered until effects of apomorphine have passed to avoid risk of charcoal aspiration
• Cats: Xylazine is the most effective; hydrogen peroxide is avoided bc it can cause hemorrhagic gastritis and syrup of ipecac is not effective and can cause cardiotoxic arrhythmias
• Dogs: Apomorphine is most effective and reversible; xylazine is not effective; hydrogen peroxide not used due to risk of gastric and esophageal ulcerations and syrup of ipecac not used due to risk of cardiotoxic arrhythmias

title: Hydrogen peroxide 3%
detail:
• Used as an emetic
• Causes emesis thru mild gastric irritation
• Can only be repeated once
• 1 teaspoon (5 mL) per 5 lbs of body weight, not exceeding 3 tablespoons (9 teaspoons); so a max dose of 45 mL
• Effective in ferrets, also used in dogs and pigs

title: Species emetics shouldn’t be used on
detail:
• Horses
• Rabbits
• Birds
• Ruminants
• Rodents

title: Syrup of ipecac
detail:
• Emetic
• No longer recommended due to possible complications
• Include lethargy, prolonged vomiting, and cardiotoxicity

title: Antiemetic drug classes
detail:
• Phenothiazine derivatives: acepromazine, chlorpromazine
• Centrally acting drugs that block dopamine receptors in chemoreceptor trigger zone (CRTZ)
• Useful in motion sickness
• Can cause hypotension and sedation
• Procainamide derivatives: Metoclopramide (Reglan)
• Central (blocks dopamine in CRTZ) and peripheral (increases gastric contraction, speeds gastric emptying, increases peristalsis, relaxes pyloric sphincter)
• Used in vomiting due to parvoviral enteritis, uremic vomiting, and chemo
• Antihistamines: Diphenhydramine
• Central (blocks H1 in CRTZ)
• Most effective in motion sickness and inner ear abnormalities
• Serotonin receptor (5-HT3) antagonists: Ondansetron (Zofran), dolasetron
• Blocks serotonin receptors on vagal nerve terminals and CRTZ
• Used for severe vomiting, including chemo
• NK-1 receptor antagonists: Maropitant citrate (Cerenia)
• Blocks binding of substance P, a NT in emetic center, to NK-1 receptors in CRTZ; mostly for motion sickness, acute vomiting (in dogs)

title: Antidiarrheals
detail:
• Loperamide
• Diphenoxylate
• Aminopentamide
• Bismuth
• Kaolin
• Pectin
• Activated charcoal

title: Laxatives
detail:
• Saline/hyperosmotic agents
• Bulk-producing agents
• Lubricants
• Surfactants/stool softeners (emollient laxatives)
• Irritants

title: Saline/hyperosmotic laxatives
detail:
• Contain poorly absorbed magnesium or phosphate anions which hold water in the tract osmotically; increased water in GI tract softens the stool
• Include lactulose, magnesium hydroxide, magnesium sulfate (Epsom salt used in birds and horses)
• Lactulose also pulls ammonia into the colon where it will change it to ammonium, which will not diffuse back into the blood, resulting in decreased ammonia concentrations—so it can be used in patients w portosystemic shunting (where blood from intestines bypasses the liver, flowing directly into general circulation, leading to toxin buildup)

title: Lactulose vs. Miralax (polyethylene glycol 3350)
detail:
• Both are osmotic laxatives; bring water in feces to soften it
• Lactulose is stronger—draws more water into the colon, but this may lead to dehydration
• Not for kidney disease due to risk of dehydration and electrolyte imbalances
• Miralax is a tasteless powder, while lactulose is an oral liquid w taste cats don’t prefer

title: Bulk laxatives
detail:
• Insoluble, water-absorbing fiber that moves stool along once swollen by water
• Include Metamucil

title: Surfactants/stool softeners (emollient laxatives)
detail:
• Soften stool by using a surfactant like docusate
• May take a week to take effect
• Include lubricants like mineral oil, white petrolatum, glycerin, cod liver oil, which ease the friction between stool and intestinal tract
• Given as enemas

title: Cathartics (purgatives)
detail: • Laxatives w a strong or harsh effect

title: Irritants
detail:
• Irritant cathartics irritate the bowel, thereby increasing peristalsis
• Include castor oil and bisacodyl
• Contraindicated in obstructed bowel and tenesmus
• Not use much in vet med

title: Antiulcer drugs
detail:
• Antacids
• H2-receptor blockers
• Proton pump inhibitors
• Cytoprotective agents

title: Antacids
detail:
• Reduce acidity in the stomach, lessening heartburn (pyrosis)
• Usually produce a chemical buffer that results in a rise in gastric pH measurements, leading to reflux not burning
• Commonly contain calcium, magnesium, aluminum

title: H2-receptor blockers
detail:
• Reduce the amount of gastric acid
• Histamine is the most important positive regulator of secretion of gastric acid (although not the only one, so acid will still be produced); w/out histamine proton pump can’t produce acid as readily and when acid levels fall ulcers can heal
• Include cimetidine, ranitidine, famotidine (Pepsin)

title: Famotidine (Pepsin)
detail:
• H2 receptor antagonist
• Decreases gastric acid production by inhibiting histamine in the stomach
• Sucralfate is most effective in an acidic environment, so famotidine should be administered 1 hour after sucralfate to prevent changing acidity and inhibiting sucralfate’s binding to ulcers

title: Proton pump inhibitors
detail:
• Work by reducing production of gastric acid secretions
• Gastric hydrogen potassium ATPase enzyme is an enzyme that functions to acidify the stomach; also called stomach’s proton pump bc acid is measured by the number of protons in the stomach
• Proton pump inhibitors denature this enzyme and stop acid production by 99%
• Indicated for animals that don’t respond to antacids and H2-receptor blockers
• Include omeprazole, pantoprazole (injectable version of omeprazole)

title: Pantoprazole
detail:
• Proton pump inhibitos used for antacid benefirs
• Injectable version of omeprazole
• Common for IBD, reflux, esophagitis, generalized GI upset
• Not compatible w dobutamine, esmolol, mannitol, midazolam, and many multivitamins, so shouldn’t be given IV in a line used to administer these drugs
• Should be given no faster than over 2 min, but usually given over 15 min

title: Sucralfate (Carafate)
detail:
• Coating agent
• Disaccharide that turns into a paste binding to ulcers—creates a protective lining along the surface of where the ulcer is formed

title: Endocrine drugs
detail:
• Thyroid drugs:
	• Hypothyroidism: Common in dogs and horses, treated w levothyroxine (T4)
	• Hyperthyroidism: Common in cats, treated w methimazole or radioactive iodine
• Adrenal drugs: Manage cortisol
	• Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing): In dogs and horses, treated w mitotane or trilostane
	• Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison): Can be spontaneous in dogs, or result from Cushing treatment, treated w fludrocortisone or prednisone+desoxycorticosterone pivalte
• Insulin

title: Production of thyroid hormones
detail:
• Hypothalamus releases thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH)
• TRH stimulates the pituitary to release thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)
• TSH stimulates the thyroid to produce T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxin)

title: Symptoms of hyperthyroidism
detail:
• Mostly in felines
• Weight loss
• Increased appetite
• Thirst
• Excessive urination
• Heart murmur and elevated HR possible

title: Hyperthyroidism drugs
detail:
• Antithyroid agents include methimazole (Tapazole)
• Obstruct enzymatic processes in the thyroid so T3 and T4 aren’t produced
• Side effects include vomiting, malaise, fatigue
• Radioactive iodine treatments
• Thyroid is the only organ that requires iodine to function, and absorbs radioactive iodine just like normal iodine (and in larger quantities bc it’s abnormal tissue)
• Radiation then destroys the tumor and/or reduces the number of hormone-producing cells

title: Hypothyroidism symptoms
detail:
• Mostly in dogs; more in large dogs
• Excessive weight gain, leading to compromised joints and compromised cardiac and respiratory status
• Thinning and dull fur
• Flakey skin and nails
• Alopecia
• Skin hyperpigmentation
• Anemia
• High blood cholesterol
• Constipation
• Poor blood clotting
• Susceptibility to infections
• Depression and mental dullness
• Cold intolerance
• Mild bradycardia

title: Hypothyroidism drugs
detail:
• Supplemental thyroid hormones
• Natural from pigs, or synthetic
• T3 dosage is hard to regulate, so T4 is common (thyroid will transform some of it to T3

title: Reproductive drugs
detail:
• Estrogen: Steroid hormones that promote female characteristics
• Estrogen diethylstilbestrol (DES): Synthetic; prevents pregnancy by causing reabsorption of fertilized egg; may cause bone marrow suppression, pyometra
• Estradiol cypionate (ECP): Semi-synthetic; used in hormone replacement therapy, to prevent embryo implantation w/in 72 hr of mating, and treat urinary incontinence
• Oxytocin: Facilitates birthing by contracting uterus and milk production
• Prostaglandin: Controls length of time that corpus luteum exists (necessary to establish and maintain pregnancy); synthetic version dinoprost accelerates birthing process
• Prostaglandin F2 alpha causes uterine contractions, relaxation of cervix, and lysis of corpus luteum
• Can return a mare to proestrus from diestrus through lysis of the corpus luteum (PGs cause lysis of corpus luteum when not pregnant)
• Progestin: Suppresses estrous
• Megestrol acetate prevents start of proestrus to diminish sexual activity
• Altrenogest used for estrus synchronization in female animals

title: Megestrol acetate
detail:
• Progestin
• Used for behavioral problems like inappropriate urination in cats and as a contraceptive in dogs

title: Insulin
detail:
• Polypeptide hormone secreted by beta cells found in the islet of Langerhans (pancreas)
• Responsible for moving glucose out of the blood and into the cells for it to be used in energy production and stored for later use

title: Diabetes mellitus
detail:
• Type 1 (insulin-dependent DM) is caused by damage to pancreatic beta cells, which result in decreased insulin production; common in dogs
• Type 2 (non-insulin-dependent DM) is a decreased sensitivity to the amount of insulin produced; common in cats

title: Insulin drugs
detail:
• Fast/short-acting insulin (regular crystalline insulin) is given when a patient needs blood sugars decreased rapidly; used to treat diabetic ketoacidosis (e.g. Humulin R (U-100))
• NPH is used for daily control of insulin; classified as an intermediate-acting hormone
• Protamine zinc insulin (PZI) is a combination of insulin and protamine, which results in an extended-release long-acting product
• Insulin facilitators are used in animals that produce some natural insulin
• Glipizide (Glucotrol) is an oral hypoglycemic agent (for type-2 DM) used only if owner refuses insulin therapy and only alongside dietary therapy

title: Insulin drug brands
detail:
• Short-acting insulin:
• Humulin R (regular insulin)
• Intermediate-acting insulin:
• Humulin N and Novolin N (NPH [Neutral Protamine Hagedorn] insulin) – U100 syringe
• Vetsulin (Lente insulin) – U40 syringe
• Long-acting insulin:
• Prozinc (Protamine Zinc) (PZI) – U40 syringe
• Lantus (Glargine) – U100 syringe
• Levemir (Detemir)

title: Insulin syringes
detail:
• Insulin can only be given by injection
• Syringes are designed for administration of a given solution strength
• U-40 has 40 units of insulin per mL
• U-100 has 100 units of insulin per mL
• Wrong syringe can result in death

title: Administering insulin
detail:
• Maintenance insulin should always be given after food to avoid hypoglycemia and seizures
• Should be stored in the refrigerator
• Only Vetsulin must be shaken, others should never be shaken bc shaking will damage the proteins and render insulin useless
• Resuspension of NPH insulin is achieved by gently rolling the bottle
• Rotate injection sites to prevent sores and pain anticipation
• Administered SC when maintaining diabetes, IV or IM in case of diabetic ketoacidosis; not given PO because it will be broken down in the stomach

title: Tx of diabetic ketoacidosis
detail:
• DKA occurs when ketone bodies derived from fatty acids are used as an energy source instead of glucose (when glucose can’t be moved in and out of cells), which leads to acidic blood and rising levels of ketones that may lead to toxicity
• Fruity smelling breath is a sign
• IV fluids and insulin therapy necessary

title: Bexagliflozin (Bexacat)
detail:
• New oral diabetic drug (recently approved in US)
• SGLT2 inhibitor
• SGLT2 is found in the kidneys; responsible for 97% of glucose resorption that would otherwise be excreted via micturition (urination)
• Inhibiting this transporter causes sugar to be dumped in the urine, preventing hyperglycemia
• Can only be used in cats who have never been on insulin

title: Immunosuppressants
detail:
• Used to diminish effects of an overactive immune system (e.g. due to autoimmune diseases) and to help body accept organ donation
• Autoimmune diseases include IMHA, autoimmune thyroiditis, autoimmune adrenalitis, myasthenia gravis, skin autoimmune diseases
• Immune-mediated eye conditions (dry eye, pannus, etc.) are treated w topical immunosuppressants like tacrolimus and cyclosporine

title: Immunosuppressant drugs
detail:
• Glucocorticoids (prednisone, triamcinolone)
• Azathioprine
• Cyclosporine (Atopica)
• Mycophenolate mofetil
• Leflunomide
• Cyclophosphamide

title: Immunostimulants
detail:
• Used to increase immune responses against viruses and cancer cells
• Diseases most commonly treated w immunostimulants are feline leukemia virus, feline immunodeficiency virus, and canine lymphoma

title: Immunostimulant drugs
detail:
• CL/Mab 321: Canine lymphoma monoclonal antibodies
• Acemannan (Immunoregulin): For treatment of FIV, FLV, and some cancers

title: GI Drugs
detail:
• Antiemetics: metoclopramide, maropitant citrate, mirtazapine
• Emetics: xylazine, apomorphine
• Antidiarrheals: loperamide, pectin, probiotics
• Laxatives: lactulose, magnesium sulfate/hydroxide, castor oil, psyllium, petroleum products
• Prokinetics: Increase peristalsis in constipation or ileus; cisapride, metoclopramide
• Antiacids, antiulcers: omeprazole, sucralfate, ranitidine
• Appetite stimulants: mirtazapine
• Digestive enzyme supplements: pancrealipase

title: Cardiovascular drugs
detail:
• Diuretics: Reduce fluid accumulation (edema) by increasing sodium and water excretion (furosemide, spironolactone)
• Inotropic agents (+ive intotropes): Improve contractility of heart muscle (pimobendan (also vasodilator), digoxin)
• Antihypertensives: Modulate BP by dilating blood vessels (ACE inhibitors (enalapril), calcium channel blockers, etc.)
• Antiarrhythmics: Control rhythm abnormalities; I-IV (I: blockade of fast sodium channels-lidocaine; 2: beta-adrenergic blockade-propranolol, atenolol; 3: potassium channel blockers-sotalol; 4: calcium channel blockade-diltiazem)
• + Anticoagulants: Heparin, aspirin (slow metabolism in cats), clopidogrel (Plavix)

title: Antiarrhythmic drug classes
detail:
• Class IA drugs: Quinidine, procainamide (block sodium channels)
• Depress myocardial excitability, prolong refractory period, decrease automaticity, increase conduction times
• Used to treat atrial and ventricular arrhythmias (long-term PO)
• Class IB drugs: Lidocaine, tocainide, mexiletine (block sodium channels)
• Stabilize myocardial cell membranes by blocking influx of sodium into the cell to prevent depolarization and decrease automaticity
• Used to treat ventricular arrhythmias, but not approved by FDA in US
• Class IC drugs not used in vet med
• Class II drugs: Propranolol, atenolol, esmolol (beta-blockers)
• Beta-adrenergic blockers (selective (Beta1 or 2) or nonselective); also increase adrenergic receptors to improve cardiac efficiency
• Used to treat atrial or ventricular arrhythmias, decrease cardiac conduction, reduce cardiac output, decrease BP
• Class III drugs not used in vet med
• Class IV drugs: Verapamil, diltiazem (calcium channel blockers
• Block calcium channels, causing depression of contractility as well as automaticity and impulse transmission

title: Propranolol
detail:
• Nonselective beta blocker (blocks both beta-1 and beta-2 receptors)
• Used to treat arrhythmias and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
• Decreases HR, BP, and cardiac output
• Slows HR and decrease arrhythmias associated w alpha-1 receptor stimulation, so can be used in chronic or post-op control of high HR due to hyperthyroidism in cats
• Atenolol works similarly
• Side effects include bradycardia, hypotension, worsening of heart failure, bronchoconstriction, heart block, and syncope (fainting)
• Dosage should be reduced gradually due to upregulation of beta-receptors—may cause tachycardia otherwise, as well as fatal arrhythmias and hypertension

title: Solatol
detail:
• Beta blocker similar to propranolol (used to treat arrhythmias and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy)
• Can be sent home as an oral form

title: Vasodilators
detail:
• Dilate arteries, veins, or both by directly acting on smooth muscle, blocking sympathetic stimulation, or preventing conversion of angiotensin I to II
• Dilation of constricted arteries decreases afterload and improves cardiac output
• Preload is also reduced bc of pooling of blood in dilated veins
• Used to treat CHF

title: Vasodilator drugs and classes
detail:
• Hydralazine – arterial vasodilator acting on smooth muscles
• Especially used in mitral valve insufficiency
• Amlodipine – arterial vasodilator; also a calcium channel blocker; causes vasodilation, so often used for hypertension
• Nitroglycerin – venous vasodilator that decreases venous return to the heart due to blood’s pooling in peripheral vessels
• Applied topical to hairless spots w gloves (make note of site so others can also avoid)
• Prazosin – mixed vasodilator; reduces BP and vasoconstriction by blocking alpha-adrenergic receptor sites
• Nitroprusside – mixed vasodilator; potent, short-term
• ACE inhibitors – mixed vasodilators that produce mild preload, significant afterload reduction

title: ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) inhibitors
detail:
• Angiotensinogen II causes vasoconstriction, which increases BP
• ACE inhibitors block conversion of angiotensinogen I to angiotensinogen II, resulting in vasodilation, which leads to decreased BP and increased cardiac output due to a decrease in preload and afterload, as well as decreased HR
• Since Angiotensinogen II is also involved in the release of aldosterone, its absence leads to increased urine output, which also helps decrease BP by decreasing fluid retention
• Include enalapril, captopril

title: Diuretics
detail:
• Exert osmotic forces in the kidneys to decrease fluid accumulation like edema and effusion
• Remove excess extracellular fluid by increasing urine flow and sodium secretion and by reducing hypertension
• Loop diuretics (Furosemide (Lasix))
• Osmotic diuretics  Mannitol (Osmitrol))
• Thiazide diuretics (hydrochlorothiazide (HydroDIURIL))
• Potassium-sparing diuretics (Spirolactone (Aldactone))

title: Loop diuretics
detail:
• Work fast
• Act at the loop of Henle
• Inhibit tubular reabsorption of sodium and promote excretion of chloride, potassium and water
• Used to treat CHF, pulmonary edema, udder edema
• Include Furosemide (Lasix)

title: Furosemide (Lasix)
detail:
• Loop diuretic
• Fast-acting
• Common diuretic used in CHF and pulmonary edema
• Potassium excretion is increased so chronic use can cause hypokalemia
• Can also cause fluid and electrolyte abnormalities, ototoxicity, GI distress, hematologic effects, weakness, restlessness

title: Side effects of loop diuretics
detail:
• Loop diuretics cause retention of sodium in the kidneys, which leads to excretion of potassium in an attempt to maintain homeostasis
• Potassium lost in the urine can lead to hypokalemia w chronic use of loop diuretic

title: Osmotic diuretics
detail:
• Act at the proximal tubule
• Limit tubular absorption by exerting high osmotic pressure in tubules
• Used to treat oliguric acute renal failure and reduce intracranial pressure
• Decreases vitreous humor via dehydration, which in turn decreases intraocular pressure
• Include Mannitol (Osmitrol)

title: Thiazide diuretics
detail:
• Inhibit reabsorption of sodium, chloride, and water
• Used to treat hypertension and nephrogenic diabetes in dogs
• Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is a disorder in which a defect in the small tubes causes passing large amounts of urine, losing too much water
• Include hydrochlorothiazide (HydroDIURIL)

title: Potassium-sparing diuretics
detail:
• Weaker
• Aka aldosterone antagonists
• Affect the collecting duct
• Causes excretion of water and sodium and reduce excretion of potassium
• Used in CHF, hypertension, etc.
• Include Spirolactone (Aldactone)

title: Respiratory drugs
detail:
• Antitussives: butorphanol, hydrocodone, dextromethorphan
• Expectorants: guaifenesin
• Mucolytics: acetylcysteine
• Decongestants: pseudoephedrine
• Bronchodilators: albuterol, aminophylline, diphenhydramine; terbutaline, metaproterenol
• Respiratory stimulants: doxampram

title: Respiratory agents
detail:
• Antihistamines to limit histamine’s effect on respiration
• Corticosteroids in case of severe lung inflammation
• Diuretics in case of excess fluid in the lungs
• Supplemental oxygen if breathing is compromised
• Stimulants (Doxapram) to increase respiratory function

title: Cough medications
detail:
• Antitussives: Used to reduce cough reflex in case of dry cough; contraindicated in productive coughs; include codeine
• Also used to treat kennel cough (tracheobronchitis)
• Include butorphanol, dextromethorphan, hydrocodone
• Expectorants: Aids in clearing congestion in productive cough by increasing fluidity of mucus so it can be expelled
• Mucolytics: Reduce the viscosity of mucus and improve airflow (e.g. acetylcysteine)

title: Antitussives
detail:
• Controlled drugs: Codeine, hydrocodone, and butorphanol
• OTC drugs: Dextromethorphan (synthetic derivative of opium found in Robitussin)

title: Causes of bronchoconstriction
detail:
• Acetylcholine release at parasympathetic nerve endings or inhibition of acetylcholinesterase—increased A levels increase respiratory secretions, reducing air flow
• Histamine release thru allergic/inflammatory processes—combines w H1 receptors on smooth muscles to cause construction and causes inflammatory response in airways leading to secretion and viscosity
• Blocking of beta2 adrenergic receptors by drugs

title: Bronchodilators
detail:
• Beta2-adrenergic agonists (stimulate beta-2 receptors and effect relaxation of fibers; stabilize mast cells and reduce histamine)
• Epinephrine, pyrilamine, albuterol, terbutaline
• Cholinergic blockers (prevent bronchoconstrictive effects of acetylcholine, but limited use)
• Antihistamines
• Methylxanthines (inhibit phosphodiesterase, which is then used to inhibit cyclic AMP to cause smooth muscle relaxation)
• Aminophylline, theophylline + cafferine, theobromine

title: Methylxanthines
detail: • Theophylline and aminophylline are methylxanthine. These inhibit phosphodiesterase, which is then used to inhibit cyclic AMP. By blocking phosphodiesterase, cyclic AMP is able to cause smooth muscle relaxation, which opens the airways.

title: Beta-receptor agonists
detail:
• Cause relaxation of smooth muscle, leading to bronchodilation
• Decrease histamine release through stabilization of the mast cell
• Albuterol is an example

title: Anticonvulsants
detail:
• Most common for long-term control of epileptic seizures are phenobarbital (first-line), potassium bromide (added if first-line not sufficient, but not in cats), and levetiracetam (Kappra); all work by influencing NT release and decreasing seizure-related neuronal activity
• Status epilepticus and cluster seizures require immediate treatment—IV diazepam (Valium, a benzo tranq) is used to stop seizure; can also be administered rectally and nasally at home

title: Immunosuppressants
detail:
• Glucocorticoids: May be short- (hydrocortisone), intermediate- (prednisone/prednisolone), or long-acting (betamethasone/dexamethasone)
• Cyclosporine A
• Azathioprine
• Tacrolimus
• Chlorambucil

title: Anti-inflammatory drugs
detail:
• Glucocorticoids: cortisone, hydrocortisone, prednisone, etc.
• NSAIDs: carprofen, robenacoxib, meloxicam, etc.
• Using corticosteroids w NSAIDs is contraindicated due to GI risks (bleeding, ulceration, perforation)

title: Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids)
detail:
• Cause immunosuppression; used to treat immune-mediated diseases in which the immune system attacks cells of the body
• Used to treat inflammation in musculoskeletal problems
• Used to shrink tumors
• Allergies will also respond to glucocorticoids
• Should not be used to treat infections due to immunosuppressant properties
• Have short-term side effects like polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, and immunosuppression-caused delay in healing
• Long-term effects include osteoporosis
• Causes decrease in lymphocytes, monocytes, and eosinophils because these stay in, or are redistributed to, the lungs, spleen, and bone marrow; may cause an increase in platelets, neutrophils, and RBC
• Chronic use causes iatrogenic hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's), and sudden discontinuation that does not allow time for adrenal gland to begin producing steroids causes iatrogenic hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s)
• Mimic elevated cortisol levels in mares and cows, which occurs at the beginning of parturition, leading to abortion if given in last weeks of gestation

title: Duration of activity of glucocorticoids
detail:
• Glucocorticoids are classified by their duration of activity
• Most topical steroids (e.g. hydrocortisone) will last 12 hours
• Prednisone and triamcinolone will last 12–36 hours
• Dexamethasone will last 48 hours or longer

title: Prednisone vs. prednisolone
detail:
• Prednisone is metabolized to prednisolone by the liver
• Cats and horses do not metabolize prednisone well, so they are given prednisolone

title: Dietary supplements and nutraceuticals
detail:
• Nutraceutical: Nondrug substance produced in purified or extracted form and administered orally
• Include S-adenosylmethionine, milk thistle, glucosamine, chondroitin

title: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
detail:
• Inability to produce sufficient amount of tears
• Tx w cyclosporine, which reduces inflammatory cells and increases number of mucin-secreting goblet cells

title: Mydriatic and miotic agents
detail:
• Mydriatic (pupil dilating) agents
• Tropicamide
• Miotic (pupil constricting) agents
• Pilocarpine and carbachol (given to glaucoma patients to transiently decrease intraocular pressure)

title: Chelation therapy
detail:
• Tx of heavy metal toxicity from lead, mercury, arsenic
• Incorporates binding (chelating) agents that bond w the metals so they can be discharged in urine
• Include calcium EDTA, succimer, dimercaprol, penicillamine
• Succimer can cross the blood-brain barrier, so able to bind to poison in the brain

title: Acetylcysteine (Mucosmyst)
detail:
• Mucolytic—decreases viscosity of respiratory secretions by changing the chemical composition of mucus
• Administered by nebulization
• Also used to treat acetaminophen toxicity (PO or IV)
• Stimulates the production of glutathione and bind w NAPQI (the byproduct of acetaminophen metabolism), reducing toxic effects
• Can cause nausea or vomiting when PO

title: Atropine
detail:
• Used to treat organophosphate poisoning (found in insecticides)
• Organophosphates interfere w breakdown of acetylcholine at cholinergic sites, causing muscarinic (salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, bradycardia, vomiting), nicotinic (weakness, paresis, stiffness, muscle tetany), and CNS signs (anxiety, hyperactivity, seizures, coma)
• Atropine addresses muscarinic and some CNS signs, not nicotine signs
• Atropine is an anticholinergic antidote—lowers secretions caused by the poisoning, expands airways that are constricted from its spasmodic effects
• Also relaxes pupillary sphincter, causing pupil dilation and facilitating ocular exams; relieves spasms so used for eye pain too
• Cats are particularly susceptible to organophosphate poisoning
• Can cause drooling, V/D, difficulty breathing due to spasms (laryngospasm, bronchospasm), tremors, muscle twitching, death

title: Ethylene glycol poisoning
detail:
• Ethylene glycol is antifreeze
• Signs include staggering, rapid pulse, abnormal behaviors, followed by vomiting, respiratory distress, agitation, seizures, acute renal failure, coma
• Tx w ethanol (drinking alcohol) and 4-methylpyrazole (Antizol-Vet) w/in 8 hours for best chance of survival

title: Rodenticide toxicity
detail:
Anticoagulant rodenticides
• Rodenticides, like Warfarin, work by preventing recycling of vitamin K, which is used in the production of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X— Factor VII is depleted first, so Prothrombin time (PT) test can be diagnostic (rodenticide will cause elevation in PT)
• Tx w vitamin K supplementation
• Should be continued until effects of rodenticide wear off
Neurotoxic rodenticides
• No treatment available

title: Organophosphate toxicity
detail:
• Found in dips, shampoos, etc. for parasite control
• Treated w atropine

title: Lead poisoning
detail: • Treated w calcium EDTA, which chelates the metal

title: Organophosphates
detail:
• Used to control endo- and ectoparasites
• Organophosphate dips should never be used on cats
• Have very narrow margin of safety
• Work by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase
• Excess acetylcholine can cause overstimulation of the nicotinic receptors in the nervous system, making them neurotoxic
• Side effects include salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, dyspnea, and bronchospasm
• Poisoning is treated w atropine; pralidoxime chloride is also used to reverse its actions (though it doesn’t treat toxicity)

title: Drugs for joint health in dogs
detail:
• Glucosamine: Produces glycosaminoglycan, which forms and repairs cartilage; supplements help replenish as it decreases w age
• Chondroitin: Main glycosaminoglycan; responsible for shock absorption and joint tissue health by providing elasticity and water retention in the cartilage; normally used in conjunction w glucosamine
• Chondroitin blocks the enzymes that try to destroy cartilage in the joints, glucosamine works to repair them

title: Arachidonic acid pathway
detail:
• Key target for anti-inflammatory drugs
• Series of biochemical reactions that convert membrane phospholipids into inflammatory mediators like prostaglandins, COX, leukotrienes, etc.—blocking the action of one or more of these decrease inflammation
• Glucocorticoids (prednisone) work on the pathway by blocking activity of phospholipase
• NSAIDs work at the level of prostaglandins by blocking activity of COX enzyme

title: Antineoplastic agents (cytotoxic chemotherapy drugs)
detail:
• Work by seeking out any cell (healthy or neoplastic) that can multiply rapidly
• Starting dose based on blood volume, which is close to body surface in sq meters
• Classified as
• Alkylating agents
• Anthracyclines
• Antimetabolites
• Plant alkaloids
• Antibiotics
• Hormonal agents

title: Side effects of chemotherapeutics
detail:
• Act against cancer cells and normal cells and target quickly dividing cells, which include the bone marrow—leads to bone marrow suppression and immunosuppression
• Also cause anorexia, diarrhea, and hypoglycemia

title: Alkylating agents
detail:
• Used to treat neoplastic disorders including osteosarcoma, hemangiosarcoma, squamous cell sarcoma
• Also have immunosuppressant properties
• Cell-cycle-nonspecific; cross-link strands of DNA to change its structure and inhibit replication
• Include cisplatin (not for cats), carboplatin, chlorambucil, cyclophosphamide
• Side effects include neutropenia, nephrotoxicity, thrombocytopenia, vomiting, hemorrhagic cystitis

title: Prodrugs
detail:
• Drugs that are inactive in their administered form
• Need to be altered in a way to become active—byproducts of the drug’s biotransformation are the active form
• Allows to increase bioavailability (usually improved GI absorption) and target specific cells (e.g. only a property unique to cancer cells activate it)
• Cyclophosphamide is an example—must be changed by the liver to activate the drug’s alkylating agents
• Enalapril becomes the active form enalaprilat
• Benazepril becomes the active form benazeprilat

title: Anthracyclines
detail:
• Used to treat various carcinomas and sarcomas
• Fungi-based
• Cell-cycle-nonspecific; bind w DNA and interfere w RNA and protein synthesis
• Include Doxorubicin
• Strong vesicant; extravasation can lead to sloughing
• Side effects include marrow suppression, cardiotoxicity, gastroenteritis, anaphylaxis
• Antihistamines may be used as premed to suppress allergic reactions

title: Antimetabolites
detail:
• Cell-cyle-specific (S phase—DNA synthesis)
• Used to treat GI and hepatic neoplasms, CNS lymphoma
• Exert cytotoxic effects by interfering w DNA synthesis
• Interrupts normal metabolic processes like cell growth
• Analogs of purine and pyrimidine take the place of real ones, which are organic nucleotides necessary to sustain cell division, resulting in failure to replicate
• Include hydroxyurea (bone marrow or lymph node cancers), cytarabine (leukemia), methotrexate (breast, head, neck, lung, bone, blood cancers), 5-fluoroucil (bowel, breast, stomach, esophageal cancers; not for cats)
• Can lead to bone marrow suppression

title: 5-Fluorouacil
detail:
• Antimetabolite
• Never used in cats due to side effects that include unprovoked aggression, dementia, and sudden death

title: Plant alkaloids (antitubulin agents)
detail:
• Cell-cycle-specific (M phase—mitosis inhibition, causing cell death)
• Used to treat carcinomas, mast cell tumors, splenic tumors
• Include vincristine and vinblastine
• Vincristine increases platelet numbers
• Can be toxic—GI disturbances, bone marrow suppression, alopecia

title: Antineoplastic antibiotics
detail: • Actinomycin D, mitoxantrone, doxorubicin, bleomycin—all created from Streptomyces

title: Antineoplastic hormonal agents
detail:
• Glucocorticosteroids (prednisone, dexamethasone)
• Signs of toxicity include PU/PD, immunosuppression, glucose intolerance, peptic ulcers, pancreatitis, hypokalemia, osteopenia, muscle wasting, cataracts

title: Safety data sheet
detail: • Safety, handling, clean-up, and disposal criteria for every drug used in the clinic

title: Controlled substances
detail:
• Prescription drugs with potential for addiction and abuse by humans
• Five schedules based on potential for abuse
	• I: High abuse potential, not used in vet med (heroine, LSD)
	• II:  High abuse potential, physical/psychic dependence (morphine, codeine, methadone, fentanyl, pentobarbital)
• Require written prescription (can’t be called in)
	• III:  Moderate abuse potential, more psychological dependence (buprenorphine, ketamine, tiletamine, acetaminophen w codeine)
	• IV: Low abuse potential (phenobarbital, butorphanol, alfaxalone, diazepam)
• V:  Low abuse potential, no DEA limit on prescriptions (antitussives (codeine))
• Xylazine may become controlled soon

title: Controlled substances log
detail:
• Shows the balance on hand of each controlled substance
• Must be kept for 2 years
• Must include:
• Patient name
• Client name
• Date
• Drug name
• Drug amount used
• For injectables, the actual amount administered as well as the drawn-up amount
• Inventory must be checked regularly to make sure it matches the log

title: Vaccine storage
detail:
• Refrigerated at 35 – 45 F
• Dedicated refrigerator
• Modified live vaccines are heat sensitive
• Adjuvanted vaccines are sensitive to freezing—adjuvant and antigen will separate and form a precipitate that can cause inflammation at the admin site
• When drawn up, must be administered w/in 30 min

title: Veterinarian-client-patient relationship (VCPR)
detail:
• Must be established before prescription of drugs
	• Veterinarian has assumed responsibility for making medical judgments and client has agreed to follow his instructions
	• Veterinarian has sufficient knowledge of the animal to make a preliminary diagnosis
	• Veterinarian is available for follow-up in case of adverse reactions
	• Veterinarian provides oversight of treatment, compliance, and outcome
• Patient records are maintained

title: Prescription labels (information of labels for drugs dispensed to clients)
detail:
• Name, address, phone number of dispensing clinic/pharmacy
• Name of prescribing veterinarian
• Client’s name
• Pet’s identifying information (name and species)
• Date dispensed
• Directions for use
• Drug name, concentration, quantity
• Following statement for controlled drugs: “Fed. law prohibits transfer of this drug to any person other than the patient…”
• Must be provided in a child-resistant container

title: Elements of a prescription (required by law)
detail:
• Vet’s name, address, phone number
• Vet’s DEA registration number
• Vet’s signature
• Drug name, concentration, quantity
• Directions for use
• Client’s name and address
• Pet’s identify information (name and species)
• Any cautionary statements
• Number of refills (not allowed for Schedule II, limited to 5 times or 6 months (whichever comes first) for Schedule III and IV)
• For controlled drugs, vet’s name must be printed

title: Drug disposal
detail: • Controlled substances that have expired or been damaged are disposed thru reverse distributors authorized to dispose them

title: Crash cart
detail:
• Catheters, tape, syringes, needles, fluid bag, Ambu-bag, and emergency drugs and dosage chart should be available
• Emergency drugs include epinephrine, atropine, naloxone, lidocaine, doxapram
• Epinephrine for anaphylaxis and stimulating the heart during CPR
• Atropine for bradycardia and possibly CPR
• Lidocaine for cardiac arrhythmias
• Doxapram for stimulating breathing (placed under the tongue of neonates)

title: Epinephrine
detail:
• Catecholamine (sympathomimetic)
• Both alpha- and beta-adrenergic agonist effects
• Administered during CPR to increase myocardial contractility
• Also causes vasoconstriction, which increases HR and AV node conduction

title: Dosage
detail: • Amount of drug per kg body weight (mg/kg, mL/kg, tablets/kg)

title: Dose
detail:
• Amount of drug that will be given with each administration (mg, mL, units [U])
Dose (mg) = Weight (kg) x Dosage (mg/kg)
• Dose (mL) = Dose (mg) ÷ Concentration (mg/mL)

title: Miscible vs. immiscible
detail:
• Miscible: Substances that form (homogeneous) solutions
• Immiscible: Substances that don’t form solutions

title: Saturation
detail:
• Solutions that contain the max. amount of a solute at a particular pressure and temperature are called saturated
• A supersaturated solution contains more solute than can be dissolved by the solvent

title: Concentrated vs. dilute
detail:
• A concentrated solution contains a large amount of solute, all of which is dissolved
• A dilute solution contains very little solute

title: Suspension
detail:
• A drug that does not dissolve in a liquid
• Mixture in which the solute is made up of very large particles
• It will settle out and must be shaken before using

title: Syrup
detail: • Contain a drug and a flavoring in sugar water or other liquid

title: Emulsion
detail: • Suspension made w oil or fat

title: Elixir Tincture
detail: • Alcohol-based solutions

title: Dilution vs. solution
detail:
• Dilution: Occurs when ratio of substance to dilutant is decreased when dilutant is added to the solution; reduction of concentration occurs
• Solution: Mixture of substances made by dissolving solids or liquids in liquids; does not precipitate

title: Concentration of a solution
detail:
• Amount of solute dissolved in the solvent
• Expressed as v/v (liquids), w/v, or w/w (solids).
• Concentration (w/vol) of 1:100 = 1 g / 100 mL = 1% = 10 mg/mL

title: Strength of a solution
detail:
• Strength of a solution (w/v) = Concentration (g/mL) =
mass (g) ÷ volume (mL)
(multiply by 100 to find percent solution)

title: Stock solution
detail:
• Product of combining pure solution (100%) w a solvent thru dilution—solvent is mixed in to reduce the concentration of the solution
C2 x V2 = C1 x V1
Ex. Prepare 2 L of a 25% solution given a 50% solution and saline
C2 = Concentration of desired solution = 25%
V2 = Volume of desired solution = 2 L
C1 = Concentration of stock solution = 50%
V1 = ?

title: Drip rates
detail:
Drip Rate = Volume of solution (mL) x Drops (ggt)/mL
Time (seconds)
Ex. 1 L is to be administered over 4 hours using a 20-dr/mL set
Volume of solution = Amount to be administered = 1000 mL
Drops/mL = 20
Time = 4 x 60
Drip Rate = 1000 x 20 / 240

title: Drop factor
detail:
• Number of drops per cc or mL of fluid
• Dependent on the diameter of IV tubing
• Common factors are 15 ggt/mL and 10 ggt/mL (macro drips), and 60 gtt/mL (micro drip)
• gtt: guttae

title: Fluid rate
detail:
• Determined based on percent dehydration (fluid deficit), ongoing losses, and maintenance requirement
= %dehydration x weight in kg
+
vol of losses (estimated or actual)
+
40-60 mL x weight in kg

title: Fluid conversion
detail: • 1 L volume of fluid = 1 kg of body weight

title: CRI
detail:
• Used to administer IV drugs over long periods of time or when the drug has a short half-life
• Added to a base solution; often IV fluids
M = (D x W x V) ÷ R
M = Amount of drug (mcg or mg) to be added to base solution
D = Dosage (mcg/kg/min or mg/kg/min)
W = weight (kg)
V = Volume of base solution (mL)
R = Infusion rate (mL/min

• F = C x 9/5 + 32
• 1 tablespoon = 15 cm3 = 15 mL = 3 teaspoons
• 1 ounce = 2 tablespoons = 30 mL

title: Factors affecting drug absorption
detail:
• Solubility of the drug
• Ionization tendency of the drug (pKa)
• pH of tissues
• Perfusion of tissues
• Volume of distribution (Vd)
• First pass effect

title: Systemic drug absorption
detail:
• Any medication given IV, IM, or SQ will be absorbed systemically
• Sucralfate is not absorbed systemically; it coats the esophagus and stomach and is not absorbed into the blood

title: First-pass effect
detail:
• Portion of a drug that is lost during the process of absorption, which typically happens in the intestinal wall and liver
• May cause large portions of drug to be readily metabolized before entering general circulation, necessitating a higher dose to be effective
• Injections used to by-pass this effect

title: Considerations for drug administration
detail:
• Vomiting patients should not be administered PO
• Catheter should be placed w a clean stick to administer chemotherapeutics, and a different vein should be used if a vein is blown (instead of going higher up) to avoid risk of extravasation of the drug

title: Bioavailability
detail:
• Fraction of a drug dose that reaches the bloodstream
• Drugs administered IV are 100% bioavailable (i.e., bioavailability of 1)
• Bioavailability is influenced by dosage form of the drug, vascularity of administration site, mechanism of absorption, and metabolism of the drug
• Bioavailability of same drug can change with route—butorphanol is 100% bioavailable IV but 20% bioavailable PO
• Drugs of plant origin (digoxin, atropine) are ineffective in cattle when administered orally because digestive microorganisms in the rumen, which will limit bioavailability

title: Five rights of drug administration
detail:
• Right to be the proper recipient (not to administer the drug to wrong patient)
• Right to receive proper medication (not to administer the wrong drug to the right patient)
• Right to receive proper dosage
• Right to receive drug via the proper route
• Right to receive medication on time

title: Extra-label use
detail:
• Allowed in 1994 under Animal Medicinal Drug Use Clarification Act (AMDUCA), illegal prior
• “Use of a drug in a manner that is not in accordance with the approved labeling”
• Includes use in another species, use for other indications, use at other dosage levels/frequencies/routes of administration
• Conditional upon a valid VCPR, absence of new approved drug w same active ingredient, documentation, and giving long withdrawal time
• FDA can prohibit ELU of some drugs (e.g., on food producing animals)
• Includes human drugs too

title: Drug compounding
detail:
• Manipulation of a drug other than as described on the label
• Classified as extra-label use
• Cannot be done from bulk chemicals (raw ingredients) or to produce a new drug
• Typically not legal to dispense compounded medications to be taken home by the client

title: Elimination of drugs
detail:
• Liver is the primary organ
• Uses enzymes to change or break down the drug, which is then called a metabolite
• Disposal thru urine, feces, sweat

title: Bound and unbound drugs
detail:
• Portion of the drug is bound to proteins in the blood, mostly albumin
• Bound portions are too large to move through fenestrations and into tissues, so only unbound portions will be distributed
• Important when highly protein-bound drugs are administered to patients with hypoproteinemia since less protein will mean more of the drug will be distributed, making side effects more likely

title: Drug clearance (Cl)
detail:
• A pharmacokinetic value describing drug elimination
• Rate at which a drug is removed from an organ or the body
• Expressed as volume of plasma cleared of drug per unit time (mL/minute)
• Used to measure efficiency of elimination and determine dosage regimen necessary to achieve a stable concentration in the blood (i.e., steady state—amount of drug administered equals amount of drug eliminated)

title: Nervous system receptors
detail:
• Sympathetic (adrenergic) system receptors:
• Alpha receptors are stimulatory
• Beta receptors are inhibitory
• Parasympathetic (cholinergic) system receptors:
• Nicotinic receptors are found at the neuromuscular junction of skeletal muscles and at the ganglionic synapses; activated by acetylcholine and nicotine
• Muscarinic receptors are found in the glands, heart, smooth muscle; activated by acetylcholine and muscarine

title: SLUD
detail: • Muscarine effects—salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation

title: Transporting molecules
detail:
• Active transport: Transport w a carrier molecule; requires energy since molecules are moved from low to high concentration
• Pinocytosis: Cell drinking (active)
• Phagocytosis: Cell eating (active)
• Facilitated transport: Diffusion/transport w a carrier protein (doesn’t require energy)
• Passive transport: Molecules freely crossing the cell membrane thru e.g. diffusion caused by concentration gradients (doesn’t require energy)

title: Nitrous oxide
detail:
• Diffuses into the alveoli and take the place of oxygen if used as an anesthetic
• Patient should be maintained on 100% oxygen for 5–10 min after gas is shut off to allow time for nitrous oxide to leave the alveoli and oxygen to take its place to avoid diffusion hypoxia

title: Halothane
detail:
• Halogenated hydrocarbon
• Risk of malignant hyperthermia
• No longer available in US

title: Blood–gas partition
detail:
