• Inhalants with a high blood–gas partition coefficient will more readily move into the tissue and blood, meaning less stays in the alveoli—this leaves a small difference in the drug concentration in the blood and alveoli (low concentration gradient), so the drug is slow to leave the blood, taking it longer for the patient to react to changes
• Blood–gas partition coefficients of anesthetics from lowest to highest: Desflurane (0.47), Sevoflurane (0.69), Isoflurane (1.1), and Halothane (2.36)

title: Desflurane
detail:
• Produces very fast changes in patient's anesthetic status due to low blood–gas partition
• Will require the most intense monitoring

title: Corticosteroid
detail:
• Corticosteroids have short-term side effects like polyuria and polyphagia, and immunosuppression can cause delayed healing
• Prednisone decreases response to antidiuretic hormone, so water is not reabsorbed and urine production increases, and animal drinks more water in response to fluid loss
• Long-term effects include osteoporosis
• Corticosteroids mimic elevated cortisol levels in mares and cows, which are found at the beginning of parturition, leading to abortions if given during last weeks of gestation
• Include dexamethasone

title: Griseofulvin
detail:
• Fungistatic antibiotic
• Used to treat dermatophyte fungal infections in dogs and cats, and ringworm in horses

title: Beta-lactamase inhibitors
detail:
• Some bacteria contain the enzyme beta-lactamase which renders antibiotics ineffective by attacking their beta-lactam rings
• Drugs can be combined with a beta-lactamase inhibitor to prevent this
• Include clavulanic acid combined w amoxicillin to make Clavamox, and sulbactam combined w ampicillin to make Unasyn

title: Clavamox
detail:
• A beta-lactamase inhibitor
• Amoxicillin combined w clavulanic acid (combination is called a potentiated aminopenicillin)
• Antibiotic to which beta-lactamase–producing bacteria are not resistant
• Used to treat UTIs, skin and soft tissue infections in cats and dogs; canine periodontal disease, bacterial cystitis in female dogs, and hepatobiliary infections in cats and dogs

title: Tramadol
detail:
• Mu-receptor opiate-like agonist
• Oral analgesic that is a synthetic analog of codeine
• Inhibits reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin
• Schedule IV drug, more recently became controlled (2014)
• Used as an alternative analgesic or adjunct for post-op or chronic pain in dogs and horses
• May cause anxiety, tremors, V/D, sedation

title: Blood-xxx barrier
detail:
• Brain
• Prostate
• Testicle
• Eye
• Joint
• Placenta

title: Induction in horses
detail:
• Detomidine, diazepam, and xylazine are commonly used
• Acepromazine causes persistent paraphimosis, increasing risk of injury

title: GI protectants
detail:
• Cover walls of the stomach and GI tract to protect from acid or irritating compounds
• Kaolin, pectin, and bismuth subsalicylate
• Kaolin and pectin are often used in combination bc there is evidence that they absorb bacteria, which decreases hypersecretion in the GI tract, which in turn decreases diarrhea
• Bismuth subsalicylate acts the same way, but is toxic to cats

title: Cyclooxygenase (COX)
detail:
• Enzyme that synthesizes prostaglandin, which regulates inflammation, pain, blood clotting, and smooth muscle contraction to promote healing and homeostasis
• COX-1 maintains physiologic functions like modulation of renal blood flow, platelet function, and gastric mucosal integrity
• COX-2 is the induced form that is associated w tissue trauma and inflammation, as well as thermoregulation
• Selective COX-2 inhibitors are preferred because nonselective COX inhibitors (like aspirin) inhibit COX-1, risking gastric ulceration

title: COX-2 selective drugs
detail:
• Deracoxib
• Carprofen
• Meloxicam

title: Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)
detail:
• Solvent added to topical medications to allow penetration of the skin (carrier of drugs)
• Causes vasodilation when applied topically
• As a carrier agent, DMSO can carry bacteria and other chemicals when penetrating the skin, so the area must be cleaned well
• Also used to reduce acute swelling from trauma, and as an anti-inflammatory in otic preparations
• Gloves should be worn to prevent penetration of the skin of the person applying the medication
• Can cause histamine release from mast cells in the skin causing inflammation in the skin; the reaction can be much worse if patient has mast cell tumors and should be avoided

title: Methionine
detail:
• Urinary acifier
• Decreases urine pH, making it more acidic, leading to dissolving of any struvite stones present and prevention of formation of new stones
• Not used as much since acidifying diets

title: Penicillin
detail:
• Bactericidal
• Most gram-positive, some gram-negative bacteria
• Has a beta-lactam ring that can be degraded by the beta lactamases, rendering it ineffective
• Methicillin, cloxacillin, dicloxacillin, oxacillin are beta-lactamase-resistant
• Doesn’t become available in cerebrospinal fluid, joints, and milk
• Kills normal GI flora and allows overgrowth of Clostridium, which causes severe, life-threatening diarrhea in rabbits and guinea pigs
• Allergic reaction is a common side effect

title: Penicillin G
detail:
• Inactivated by gastric acid, so not given PO
• Procaine and benzathine will delay its absorption (thus decreasing the rate at which it enters the blood), leading to lower concentrations but longer duration of activity

title: Calcium gluconate (Tums)
detail:
• Used to treat hypocalcemia (e.g. after parathyroidectomy or during pregnancy or lactation)
• Patient should be monitored w EKG due to risk of cardiotoxicity
• Development of a prolonged PR interval, wide QRS, and bradycardia also possible
• In case of hyperkalemia, it may be used antagonize the cardiotoxic effects of potassium like prolonged depolarization/repolarization causing bradycardia and atrial standstill

title: Guaifenesin
detail:
• Muscle relaxant, sedative, and expectorant
• As muscle relaxant, it is used to induce horses; usually in 5% dextrose (more common use)
• As an expectorant, it increases fluidity of mucus to make it more easily removed

title: Side effects of sulfonamides
detail:
• Crystal formation in kidneys leading to hematuria and crystalluria (dehydration will increase risk of crystalluria)
• Triple sulfas (new gen.) were developed to decrease formation of crystals
• Decreased tear production causing keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
• Allergic reactions, especially in Doberman pinschers
• Thrombocytopenia
• Leukopenia
• Liver dysfunction
• Anemia
• So not commonly used

title: Bacteria’s method of resistance to sulfonamides
detail:
• Sulfonamides prevent bacteria from synthesizing folic acid, inhibiting metabolism of proteins and nucleic acids
• Bacteria are capable of switching to using the host's folic acid, thus becoming resistant to sulfonamide

title: NSAID in cats
detail:
• NSAIDs have a longer half-life in cats due to a deficiency in glucuronic acid (e.g. aspirin half-life is 40 hours in cats vs. 8 hours in dogs bc it is eliminated via conjugation w glucuronic acid)
• NSAIDs should not be used in cats or the dose and dosing interval should be adjusted (e.g. aspirin is given w dosing intervals of at least 2 days)
• Ibuprofen, carprofen, and naproxen should never be given to cats

title: Pain management in horses
detail:
• A combination of an alpha-2 agonist and an opioid is used for immediate relief for acute colic pain (e.g. detomidine + butorphanol)
• Butorphanol (opioid) is used for colic pain
• Diclofenac sodium (NSAID) is used for joint pain and inflammation
• Firocoxib (NSAID) is used for pain associated w equine osteoarthritis
• Flunixin meglumine (NSAID) is used for analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects, e.g. in endotoxemia

title: Generic vs. trade. vs. chemical name
detail:
• Generic name (aka nonproprietary name or compendial name): Name found in the United States Pharmacopoeia (USP); usually the active ingredient
• Trade name (aka proprietary name): Name given by the drug company
• Chemical name: Describes the chemical structure of the drug (e.g. 2-(2-methyl-5-nitro-1H-imidazol1-1yl)ethanol for metronidazole)

title: Amitraz
detail:
• Used to treat generalized demodicosis (demodectic mange) and as flea/tick infestation prevention in collars
• Not used in dogs younger than 4 months
• May be toxic to cats and rabbits
• Contraindicated if taking MOI
• Yohimbine is used in case of overdose

title: Enrofloxacin (Baytril)
detail:
• Not effective for anaerobes
• Concentrates heavily in urine, so good for UTIs
• First line of treatment for dogs w kidney infections (pyelonephritis)
• Quickly develops resistance, but still in use due to cost, etc.
• Available for small animals (22.7 mg/mL) and large animals (100 mg/mL)
• Doesn’t kill normal GI flora, so safe for rabbits
• Avoided in horses and young, growing animals because it causes lesions on the cartilage
• Cats are susceptible to retinal damage in higher doses

title: Metronidazole
detail:
• Synthetic antibacterial and antiprotozoal
• FDA bans use in food animals
• Works well in anaerobic environments
• Administered PO or IV only
• Used to treat Giardia, trichomoniasis, enteritis, ulcerative colitic, hepatic encephalopathy
• Tetanus favors anaerobic environments, so best med is metronidazole
• Has anti-inflammatory properties in GI tract, so sometimes used as sole treatment for inflammatory bowel disease
• Can cause CNS signs like disorientation, head tilt, seizures, as well as anorexia, hepatotoxicity, V/D

title: Trimethoprim and ormetoprim
detail:
• Combined w sulfonamides to potentiate their effects by inhibiting a step in the folate synthesis pathway
• Sulfadimethoxine/Ormetoprim is a combination used to treat skin and soft tissue infections in dogs caused by E. coli and S. aureus

title: Sulfadimethoxine
detail:
• Only drug approved for treatment of coccidiosis in dogs
• Sulfanomide
• Side effects include crystalluria, polyarthritis, bone marrow suppression, keratoconjunctivitis sicca

title: Fiber systems associated w pain
detail:
• Transmission of impulses in the second step of the production of pain sensation takes place thru 2 fiber systems
• Type C unmyelinated fibers are responsible for dull, poorly localized pain in humans
• Type A delta fibers are responsible for sharp, localized pain
• Both fibers carry impulses to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord (where modulation occurs)

title: Kitty magic
detail: • Ketamine + Dexmedetomidine + Butorphanol

title: Etomidate
detail:
• Ultrashort-acting, non-barbiturate hypnotic anesthetic
• Used esp. in high-risk patients due to very limited depressive effects on cardiovascular and respiratory systems
• Can also decrease increased ocular and intracranial pressure
• Higher margin of safety than propofol

title: Diazepam
detail:
• Benzodiazepine
• Used to stop seizure activity, to cause sedation, and to stimulate appetite in cats
• Works by binding to GABA receptors and decreasing neuronal firing
• Marked sedative effects in rodents and rabbits unlike dogs and cats) and used in combination w other agents to produce balanced anesthesia; administered IP, IM, IV
• Absorbed by plastic, so should be drawn up right before use
• Stored at room temp, no light exposure

title: Midazolam (Versed)
detail:
• Benzodiazepine
• Very similar to diazepine but has greater potency
• Marked sedative effects in rodents and rabbits unlike dogs and cats) and used in combination w other agents to produce balanced anesthesia; administered IP, IM, IV

title: Acepromazine
detail:
• Adrenergic blockers
• Phenothiazine tranquilizer
• Blocks alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, causing peripheral vasolidation
• Sedative, preanesthetic adjunct; also used for motion sickness
• Causes vasodilation
• Contraindicated in epileptic animals bc it lowers seizure threshold (though not clear)
• Peripheral vasodilation leads to hypotension
• Depresses brain’s thermoregulatory center, so not for use in hypothermic animals
• Can cause penile relaxation in horses and bulls, which can lead to injury if prolonged, so not used for breeding horses/bulls

title: Ketamine
detail:
• Dissociative; NMDA receptor antagonist
• NMDA receptors relay pain information to the brain, so ketamine may help prevent windup, allow lower doses of opioids, and prevent severe acute pain and chronic pain
• Unlike other anesthetics, reflexes remain intact in dissociatives
• Often combined w diazepam to promote muscle relaxation
• Increases cerebral blood flow, leading to increased intracranial pressure, so not for use in cases of intracranial disease
• Side effects include tachycardia, hypertension, apneustic breathing, muscle rigidity, increased salivation
• Cats tend to keep eyes open

title: Side effects of morphine
detail:
• Often causes vomiting
• All opioids can cause constipation
• May cause pruritus due to histamine release
• May cause excitement in horses
• Stimulates antidiuretic hormone, decreasing urine production

title: Alfaxalone
detail:
• Comparable to propofol—also used for sedation in short procedures and for induction, and similar in response and recovery times
• Approved in 2014

title: Propofol
detail:
• Hypnotic
• Nonbarbiturate hypnotic agent used to induce anesthesia
• Lasts 2-5 min
• Rapid recovery (10 min) when used alone, but often used as an induction agent as part of a multimodal anesthesia protocol

title: Storing propofol
detail:
• Ideally kept refrigerated once open and discarded after 6 hours—contains egg, lecithin, and soybean oil, all of which encourage bacterial growth
• Propofol-28 can be kept at room temperature for 28 days as long as aseptic technique is used

title: Cyclosporine (Atopica)
detail:
• Immunosuppressant
• Also used for pruritus and KCS

title: Anipryl
detail:
• Used for canine cognitive dysfunction (old dog senility or dementia)
• Works by increasing dopamine in the brain

title: Iodophor
detail:
• A compound made up of iodine and a carrier that allows the iodine to be released w time, providing prolonged activity
• A "tamed" iodine antiseptic (like Povidone-Iodine) used for broad-spectrum disinfection to kill bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa
• Used as a skin prep before surgery, wound treatment, etc.
• May need to be applied more than once to provide adequate disinfection
• Can be inactivated by organic materials, so area should be thoroughly cleaned before application
• Diluted to avoid tissue irritation (iodine is irritant)

title: Scientific names of vitamins
detail:
• Vitamin B1 – thiamine
• Vitamin B2 – riboflavin
• Vitamin B12 – cyanocobalamin
• Vitamin C – ascorbic acid
• Vitamin D2 – ergocalciferol
• Vitamin D3 – cholecalciferol
• Vitamin E – alpha-tocopherol

title: Dirlotapide
detail:
• Used for obesity in dogs
• Acts by preventing the release of lipoproteins into the blood

title: Frontline
detail:
• Plus has an insect growth regulator that kills flea eggs/larvae
• Gold has fipronil to kill adult fleas and ticks and S-methoprene and pyriproxyfen to kill eggs/larvae
• Gold kills faster than Plus

title: Fipronil
detail:
• Topical flea/tick preventive
• Kills adult fleas and all ticks
• Frontline Plus and Gold, Effipro/Effitix

title: Advantix (imidacloprid and permethrin)
detail:
• Tick and flea preventative
• Repels mosquitos

title: Heartgard (Ivermectin)
detail:
• Heartworm preventative
• Also controls hookworms and roundworms (not tapeworms)

title: Revolution (Selamectin)
detail:
• Preventative for heartworm, fleas, ear mites, mange, hookworms, and roundworms
• Plus treats/prevents heartworm, fleas, ticks, hookworms, roundworms, ear mites
• Systemic absorption takes 48 hours, so pets shouldn’t be bathed before then

title: Tricyclics
detail:
• Used to treat separation anxiety, obsessive disorders like lick granuloma or tail chasing, fearful aggression, hyperactivity, and urine marking
• Work by preventing reuptake of norepinephrine and/or serotonin
• Include clomipramine (Clomicalm), amitriptyline, imipramine
• Clomipramine is a selective inhibitor for serotonin reuptake

title: Biological response modifiers
detail:
• Agents that alter the relationship bw tumor and host to allow host to mount an antitumor response
• Adjunct to chemotherapy protocols—used to restore immune response compromised by chemo drugs
• Include monoclonal antibodies, interferons, thymosins, cytokines/lymphokines

title: Monoclonal antibodies
detail:
• A biological response modifier
• Antibodies designed to recognize one specific target
• Have cytotoxic effects on tumor cells or are attached to chemo agents for direct delivery to tumor cells

title: Interferons
detail:
• A biological response modifier
• Chemicals produced by leukocytes, fibroblasts, and epithelial cells w antitumor, antiviral, immunoregulatory effects
• Used to treat or increase life expectancy of cats w FIP or FeLV

title: Insect growth regulators
detail:
• Drugs that increase insect growth regulators naturally found in flea larvae to interrupt development of eggs
• Found in flea collars and premise/pet sprays
• Include methoprene (in Frontline), fenoxycarb, and pyriproxyfen (in Advantix/Advantage II)

title: Acyclovir (Zovirax)
detail:
• Ocular antiviral—used to treat feline herpes ocular virus
• Cats are sensitive (may cause fatal myeloid dysplasia) so famciclovir preferred

title: Methocarbamol (Robaxin-V)
detail:
• Muscle relaxant used in dogs, cats, horses
• Often used to treat muscle spasms associated with skeletal muscle trauma (such as a dog with back pain)
• Used to treat intervertebral disk syndrome, strain, spasms, tying up in horses

title: Phenylbutazone
detail:
• NSAID used in dogs and horses
• Analgesic for mild to moderate pain, anti-inflammatory, antipyretic
• Used in horses for colic and lameness
• Only IV—will cause sloughing of tissue
• Side effects include GI bleeding, anorexia, bone marrow suppression

title: Pentobarbital
detail:
• Main component of euthanasia solutions
• C-II on its own, C-III if combined w other agents (such as a dye to identify it as a euthanasia solution)

title: Flunixin (Banamine)
detail:
• NSAID
• Analgesic, antipyretic, anti-inflammatory effects
• Effective for visceral pain
• Commonly used for pain associated w colic in horses (IV or IM)
• Not an anticoagulant
• Extra-label use in dogs; may cause V/D, nephrotoxicity, gastric ulceration w long-term use

title: Potassium chloride
detail:
• Used to supplement deficits in hypokalemia
• May be caused by anorexia, diuresis, diarrhea
• Signs include weakness, lethargy, vomiting
• Side effects include hyperkalemia (may cause cardiac conduction disturbances)
• Contraindicated in hyperkalemia, renal failure, Addison’s acute dehydration
• Should not be delivered at a rate of more than 0.5 mEq/kg/h; may cause cardiac arrest

title: Phenylpropanolamine
detail:
• Adrenergic agent (like epinephrine or albuterol)
• Used to treat urinary incontinence in dogs—affects urethral sphincter (brand name Proin)
• Also a decongestant and bronchodilator
• Used w caution w glaucoma, prostatic hypertrophy, hyperthyroidism, DM, cardiovascular disorders, hypertension

title: Gabapentin (Neurontin)
detail:
• Anticonvulsant
• Commonly used for chronic pain and acute and chronic neuropathic pain
• Can be used for anxiety and social phobias

title: Affinity
detail:
• Tendency of a drug to combine w a receptor
• Agonists have high affinity and high efficacy
• Efficacy refers to the degree w which the drug produces the desired response
• Partial agonists have less affinity and efficacy

title: Hypertrophy
detail: • Increase in the size of an organ

title: Effects of cardiac disease on drugs
detail:
• Because cardiac disease affects blood flow to the GI tract (absorption), tissues (distribution), liver (metabolism), and kidneys (elimination), it can greatly affect drug reactions
• Drugs and their doses should be chosen considering cardiac disease

title: Agencies involved in drug regulations
detail:
• FDA approves new medications and anything taken orally
• EPA regulates topical medications
• USDA regulates vaccines
• DEA regulates controlled substances

title: Enteric coating
detail:
• Acid-resistant; prevents drug from dissolving in acidic environments like the stomach
• Activated in alkaline environments like the small intestine
• Should not be split into smaller doses

title: Repository drug
detail: • Drug w sustained, long-lasting release

title: Compensatory mechanisms of the heart
detail:
• In case of heart failure, cardiac output is reduced, which leads to hypotension and poor tissue perfusion
• Compensatory mechanisms go into effect to increase BP and improve blood supply to tissues
• First, sympathetic nervous system is stimulated—increases HR and causes constriction of small arteries, which increases BP
• Next, renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system is activated by release of renin from poorly perfused kidneys—renin causes angiotensinogen to be converted to angiotensin I, which is converted by ACE to angiotensin II, which causes further vasoconstriction and stimulates adrenal gland to release aldosterone—this causes kidney to retain water, which increases blood volume to improve tissue perfusion
• Constriction leads to increased afterload and increased blood volume increases preload, which in the long-run is harmful bs it necessitates more strenuous activity by the heart

title: Ototoxic drugs
detail:
• Chlorhexidine (should be diluted 1:100 w saline if to be used to clean ear)
• Aminoglycosides (gentamicin, amikacin, neomycin)
• Furosemide (Lasix)

title: Nephrotoxic drugs
detail:
• Aminoglycosides (gentamicin, amikacin, neomycin)
• Also ototoxic
• Flunixin (Banamine)
• Alkylating agents (Cisplatin)
• Amphotericin B (ocular/systemic antifungal)

title: Monitoring for nephrotoxicity
detail:
• Damage to the kidneys is first evident by presence of casts and protein in the urine; indicates damage to renal tubules
• BUN and creatinine will not become elevated until damage to kidneys is extensive

title: Route increasing risk of nephrotoxicity
detail:
• CRI—If given as bolus (or any other way) plasma concentration can drop between doses, drug will move out of the cell and into the plasma, preventing its accumulation in the kidney
• Accumulation in the kidney due to constant plasma concentration will increase risk of nephrotoxicity

title: Hepatotoxic drugs and drugs metabolized in the liver (can’t be used in case of liver disease)
detail:
• Phenobarbital
• NSAIDs
• Benzodiazepines
• Buprenorphine (Simbadol)
• Metronidazole (Flagyl)

title: WBCs
detail:
• Neutrophils: First responders to infections
• Lymphocytes: Memory specialists that recognize non-self-antigens and coordinate immune responses; become T, B, or natural killer cells
• T cells fight off viral infections and cancers
• B cells produce antibodies, mark invaders for elimination by the immune system
• NKCs and cytotoxic T cells destroy foreign material; antibodies and helper T cells stimulate other components of the immune system to do so
• Monocytes: Cleanup crew that removes damaged cells and debris
• Eosinophils: Specialists that combat parasites and respond to allergies
• Basophils: Inflammatory response team that releases histamine and other chemicals

title: Nutraceuticals
detail:
• Nutritional supplements used as therapeutic agents
• Produced in a purified or extracted form that is used to improve health and well-being
• Include glucosamine, omega-3 fatty acids, and S-adenosylmethionine (Sam-e).

title: Coccidiostat
detail:
• Antiprotozoal
• Used in livestock, especially poultry, to prevent or treat coccidiosis

title: Amphojel/Basaljel
detail:
• Amphojel is aluminum hydroxide and Basaljel is aluminum carbonate
• Used both as phosphate binders and antacids
• Provided w meal to bind the phosphorus in the food, preventing or treating hyperphosphatemia
• Used to treat rumen acidosis (rumen overload) in ruminants

title: Sodium phosphate enemas
detail: • Absorbed thru GI and into the blood, leading to hypernatremia and hypophosphatemia, which can result in death in cats and small dogs

title: Mirtazapine
detail:
• Appetite stimulant
• Alpha-2 receptor antagonist and serotonin receptor antagonist
• Side effects include sedation, hypotension, tachycardia

title: Spinal anesthesia
detail:
• Drugs are injected into epidural or subdural space
• Subdural space is inside the dura mater (injection into the cerebrospinal fluid in the subdural space is called intrathecal route)
• Epidural space is outside the dura mater but inside spinal canal
• Spinal epidurals decrease ability to urinate, so bladder size should be monitored

title: Idiosyncratic drug reaction
detail:
• Unusual or unexpected reaction to a drug
• Not dose dependent; doesn’t affect many patients
• Often associated w immune response
• All adverse reactions should be reported to the manufacturer or FDA

title: Use of antibiotics for pneumonia
detail: • Antibiotics should be continued for 2 weeks after signs of the pneumonia are no longer evident on radiographs

title: Molality vs. molarity
detail:
• Molarity: Number of moles of solute per liter of solution
• Molality: Number of moles of solute per kilogram of solvent

title: Nerve growth factor
detail:
• One of the chemical mediators that contribute to peripheral sensitization, neurogenic inflammation, and noxious signal generation interpreted as pain
• Elevated in osteoarthritic joints
• Drugs block the receptor-mediated signaling cascade induced by NGF, reducing pain and limiting further NGF release
• Librela (bedinvetmab) is a monthly injectable anti-NGF monoclonal antibody used to treat osteoarthritis in dogs
• Solensia is a similar, earlier drug for cats

title: Malignant hyperthermia
detail:
• Can be caused by halothane
• Treated w dantrolene (Dantrium), a muscle relaxant that will bind to receptors, preventing or decreasing excitation and contraction of skeletal muscle

title: Naming conventions for microbes
detail:
• Bacteria
• Binomial nomenclature in Latin
• Italicized, genus capitalized
• Often ends in -coccus, -bacillus, -spirillum, -bacter
• Fungi
• Binomial nomenclature
• Latin genus names like Candida, Aspergillus, Cryptococcus
• Viruses
• Ends in “virus,” often includes disease, host, location
• Protozoa
• Keywords like cysts/trophozoites, oocysts, flagellated, amoeboid, apicomplexan, vector-borne, intracellular parasite

title: Aerotolerant organism
detail: • An organism that can survive in an environment with or without oxygen

title: Desiccation-tolerant organisms
detail: • Organisms that can live in environments that lack moisture (or is dehydrated)

title: Temperature ranges for drug storage
detail:
• Cold – up to 46 F (8 C)
• Cool – 46 to 59 F (8 to 15 C)
• Room temp – 59 to 86 F (15 to 30 C)
• Warm – 86 to 104 F (30 to 40 C)
• Excessive heat – above 104 F (40 C)

title: Psychotropic medications
detail:
• Drugs that affect mental state; potentially treat behavior problems
• Include alprazolam, a benzodiazepine

title: FARAD
detail:
• Food Animal Residue Databank
• Repository of residue avoidance information and educational materials
• Include withdrawal times
• Food animals include all in the species, not just the population that is meant for food production

title: Side effects of benzodiazepines in horses
detail:
• Ataxia
• Muscle fasciculations
• Weakness
• Used w secondary medications like alpha-2 agonists to avoid side effects

title: Bismuth
detail:
• Coats the GI tract acting as a protectant
• Has anti-inflammatory properties
• Blocks prostaglandins that increase the absorption of fluids, which decreases fluid moving into the stool and decreases diarrhea
• Decreases hypermotility of the stomach
• Can cause salicylate toxicity in cats
